cat.gencat.ctti.canigo.arch.security.saml.authentication.filter

Class SAMLProcessingCapturingFilter

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.springframework.web.filter.GenericFilterBean
      • org.springframework.security.web.authentication.AbstractAuthenticationProcessingFilter
        • org.springframework.security.saml.SAMLProcessingFilter
          • cat.gencat.ctti.canigo.arch.security.saml.authentication.filter.SAMLProcessingCapturingFilter
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    javax.servlet.Filter, org.springframework.beans.factory.Aware, org.springframework.beans.factory.BeanNameAware, org.springframework.beans.factory.DisposableBean, org.springframework.beans.factory.InitializingBean, org.springframework.context.ApplicationEventPublisherAware, org.springframework.context.EnvironmentAware, org.springframework.context.MessageSourceAware, org.springframework.core.env.EnvironmentCapable, org.springframework.web.context.ServletContextAware

    public class SAMLProcessingCapturingFilter
extends org.springframework.security.saml.SAMLProcessingFilter
    Extends Spring Security SAML processing filter for the Assertion Consumer Service (or webSSO in Springspeak) in order to:
    • Extract the assertion in its base64 form and keep it in the HTTP session, so that it can later be retrieved and exchanged for a JWT token.
    • Validate the assertion signature. Spring Security SAML Extension security policies look for a Signature tag to validate in the XML tags right under the top-most SAMLResponse tag. These tags are Issuer, Status and the (Encrypted)Assertion tag, so Spring should in the case of not finding a signed SAMLResponse look inside the (Encrypted)Assertion tag, which is what we shall be doing. It has been tested that IdP such as Shibboleth, ADFS and SSOCircle sign the Assertion, not the whole SAMLResponse.
    Author:
    cscanigo
